idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.2.1350

descript.abstract: Harford County, MD Lidar Elevation Data.
descript.purpose: Surdex acquired and processed LIDAR data over the entire county. This data will support the generation of 1"=100' scale orthophotos. The Lidar LAS data has been classified to bare-earth as well as first-return points.
descript.supplinf: The data is broken down into a tile index supplied to the county. There are 1,348 tiles and each tile covers approximtely 3,000' by 3,000'.

idinfo.useconst: Harford County shall not be held liable for any errors in this data. This includes errors of omission, commission, errors concerning content of the data, and relative and positional accuracy of the data. This data cannot be construed to be a legal document.

cntorgp.cntorg: Harford County Department of Planning and Zoning

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.2.1350

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

cntperp.cntorg: Harford County Department of Planning and Zoning

procstep.procdesc:
LiDAR data for this project was acquired using a Leica ALS50-II system. The ALS50-II supports acquisition with pulse rates up to 150,000 Hz and up to 4 ranges and three intensities per laser pulse.
The flight was planned at multiple flying heights and sensor settings, some of which are listed below. flying height field-of-view nominal swath width average point density 10,000 ft AGL 20 degrees 3526 ft 0.62 points per sq. m. 6,000 ft AGL 33 degrees 3554 ft 0.91 points per sq. m. 3,000 ft AGL 61 degrees 3532 ft 1.38 points per sq. m.
Note that all scenarios produce very similar swath width. This allows a single flightplan to be sent to the field, and the flying height and sensor settings can be chosen on prevailing flight conditions. All scenarios are valid in terms of required point density and accuracy for the project. Since actual swath width on the ground varies with terrain elevation, a line spacing of 2900 ft was used to produce overlapping lines and ensure no line-to-line data gaps. Data acquisition was performed between 3/31/2007 and 4/10/2007 with flights at either 3,000 and 6,000 ft flying heights. There were no 10,000 ft flights.
Ground processing of the raw airborne acquisition data involves processing the dual-channel airborne GPS data along with IMU data from the sensor into a final solution for aircraft position/attitude ( trajectory ) as a function of time. The ground processing is done using vendor provided software for the sensor. In the case of the ALS50-II, the software used is Leica's own IPAS Pro software, and GrafNav software from Waypoint Consulting. Once the final aircraft trajectory is computed, raw sensor range data can be processed into a point cloud in ground/map coordinates. This processing is also done in the ALS Post Processor, another vendor provided software package. The resulting point cloud is stored in LAS format. The LAS format is a binary exchange format that stores metadata in addition to (X,Y,Z) coordinate for each point. This metadata includes: time, flightline, point classification, first/second/return numbers.
The LiDAR point cloud in ground/map coordinates is then processed using a combination of commercial and Surdex proprietary software packages. The GeoCue software product is used for overal process management, using lower level tools from TerraSolid along with in-house tools. The basic process is to classify LiDAR points as bare-earth, vegetation, building, water, or other. The classified point data are then used to produce various deliverable formats.

horizpa.horizpar: This Lidar data is accurate to support the generation of 1"=100' scale digital orthophotos using National Mapping Accuracy Specifications. This equates to an RMSE of 1.5' +/- horizontally.

vertacc.vertaccr: This Lidar data is accurate to support the generation of 1"=100' scale digital orthophotos using National Mapping Accuracy Specifications. This equates to an RMSE of 1.2' +/- horizontally.
